page.title: 08QUEENS GARDENS HULL
page.content: The area now known as Queens Gardens was once the site of Hulls first enclosed dock - excavated between 1774 and 1778. The dock was the first of its kind outside London and covers a total area of 11 acres. The original name of the dock was 'The Old Dock' but it was re-named 'Queens' when Queen Victoria visited Hull in 1854. Today the site is an open amenity area with lakes and lawns. There is a cafe and people, mainly shop and office workers, enjoy lunchtime entertainment in the summer. At the north end of the gardens is a plaque which depicts Robinson Crusoe from the novel by Daniel Defoe. Crusoe stated his illfated voyage from Hull and, according to the novel he remained on his desert island for 28 years 2 months and 19 days, wishing he could return to Hull.
